The Future of Work Is Here: Digital Work Instruction and Augmented Reality
text:
As industries continue to digitize and automation becomes more prevalent, the need for efficient and accurate work instructions is more important than ever. Digital work instruction software is revolutionizing how companies train and onboard employees, and it's only the beginning.

One of the most exciting developments in digital work instruction is the integration of augmented reality. Imagine overlaying digital instructions directly onto the work environment, allowing employees to understand and complete tasks with precision quickly. This technology can increase productivity, reduce errors, and improve overall safety in the workplace.

Many companies are already using digital work instruction software and augmented reality to train employees in manufacturing, assembly, and maintenance. But the potential applications go far beyond that. From construction and logistics to healthcare and education, the possibilities are endless.

As we move towards a more digitized and automated future, digital work instruction software and augmented reality will become essential tools for companies looking to stay competitive.

https://vksapp.com/what-are-digital-work-instructions

Show HN: Create QuickBooks Sale Receipt from 3rd Party Transactions
text:
Hello everyone. I created a very niche product for my payment gateway customers. They are struggling with the manual process of marking transaction(s) as received in QuickBooks for their franchisor reports and bookkeeping.

Paysync.ca turns a manual process into an almost fully automated solution by turning a transaction into a Sale Receipt.

We currently support NMi gateways or affiliated gateways and soon importing CSV files.

If you are interested you can join the beta program at https://paysync.ca Hacker News registrants will be granted access in front of the line.

Have a good day!

Ask HN: What is the “proper” way to do error-handling in TypeScript?
text: Folks, I feel like I'm losing my mind. Typescript's concept that `error` is either `any` or `unknown` feels like such a massive gaping problem. I get that it's Javascript's fault for not having a rigorous error typing system. What are some strategies you guys use to expose the kinds of errors your libs throw, or capture the errors other people's code throws?

Ask HN: Isn't it time for a new AI acronym?
text:
Having been interested in AI for decades, "AI" to me has always meant "human-level machine intelligence", aka "strong AI".

When the term "ML" started to become popular, I felt it was more like "data collection" than "learning". ML seemed a far cry from developing a machine that could learn and be taught, like humans can learn and be taught.

Now with the problem of ChatGPT's reputation for spewing out unreliable nonsense, it seems we need a new acronym for that flavor of AI. Perhaps "FAI", for Fake Artificial Intelligence?

title: Testing the “world’s first robot lawyer,” a thread
Ask HN: Is anyone building a question answering system using the HN corpus?
text:
Today, if someone wants to know what the HN community knows/thinks about a topic, they can either:

A) Search past HN comments on hn.algolia.com, or

B) Post a new 'Ask HN'.

LLMs could provide a new way to find answers within a corpus. These have been described elsewhere, e.g.

- https://github.com/openai/openai-cookbook/blob/main/examples/Question_answering_using_embeddings.ipynb

- https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=34477543

I keep expecting someone (maybe minimaxir or simonw?) to post a 'Show HN: Get your question answered by the collective wisdom of HN', but I no one has so far (unless I missed the submission?).

Is someone already working on this?
